title: Fix issue on `sky down` when ~/.ssh/config is missing
body: Fixes issue in #138

title: Add `sky start`.
body:
Problem: interactive node reuse
```bash
  sky gpunode -c cs285 --gpus=V100
  sky stop cs286

  # Does not restart:
  # sky.exceptions.ResourcesMismatchError: Requested resources do not match the existing cluster.
  #   Requested: 1x {None(None, {'K80': 1})}
  #   Existing: 1x {None(None, {'V100': 8})}
  # To fix: specify a new cluster name, or down the existing cluster first: sky down sky-gpunode-zongheng
  sky gpunode -c cs285

  # OK, but non-intuitive / may forget the original resources flags.
  sky gpunode -c cs285 --gpus=V100
```
Solution: `sky start`
```
  # Just need to use the cluster name (sky status).
  sky start cs285
```
This also handles restarting a stopped cluster that is originally launched by a task.yaml, but we don't want to use `sky run ... task.yaml` to restart it (e.g., we don't want to run the task).

test 'sky run' reuse
```bash
  sky run -c min examples/minimal.yaml
  sky ssh min
  touch hi
  sky stop min

  # Shows STOPPED.
  sky status

  # Writes a new config/user/min.yml where file_mounts/setup/workdir are empty.
  sky start min
  sky ssh min
  ls hi

  # Writes a new config/user/min.yml where file_mounts/setup/workdir are filled in.
  # file_mounts/setup/workdir are re-processed (idempotent).
  sky run -c min examples/minimal.yaml
```


test n-node clusters
```bash
sky run -c gang2 examples/multi_hostname.yaml
sky stop gang2
sky start gang2

# Works.
sky exec -c gang2 examples/multi_hostname.yaml
# Executing a different task works too.
sky exec -c gang2 examples/minimal.yaml
```

Tested smoke tests which pass except file mounts (tracked in #140).

title: [backend] Failed-to-setup clusters have no Ray processes after fixing setup
body:
Encountered this bug in `examples/using_file_mounts.yaml`.  Its setup uses `apt-get install`, which can give
```
E: Could not get lock /var/lib/dpkg/lock-frontend - open (11: Resource temporarily unavailable)
E: Unable to acquire the dpkg frontend lock (/var/lib/dpkg/lock-frontend), is another process using it?
```
This is expected for a fresh VM. This means Ray's never started (`head_start_ray_commands` is after `setup_commands`), while the VM is indeed up.

After a few mins, run this example again, which will get past this apt lock issue.  It then proceeds to sync some cloud files, then it will execute a Ray program (codegen-d by Sky), which fails, because there are no Ray processes. 
```bash
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/home/ubuntu/.sky/sky_app/sky_app_10sf0_dc", line 12, in <module>
    ray.init('auto', namespace='__sky__', log_to_driver=True)
  File "/opt/conda/lib/python3.7/site-packages/ray/_private/client_mode_hook.py", line 89, in wrapper
    return func(*args, **kwargs)
  File "/opt/conda/lib/python3.7/site-packages/ray/worker.py", line 818, in init
    redis_address, _, _ = services.validate_redis_address(address)
  File "/opt/conda/lib/python3.7/site-packages/ray/_private/services.py", line 325, in validate_redis_address
    address = find_redis_address_or_die()
  File "/opt/conda/lib/python3.7/site-packages/ray/_private/services.py", line 239, in find_redis_address_or_die
    "Could not find any running Ray instance. "
Shared connection to 34.105.5.31 closed.
ConnectionError: Could not find any running Ray instance. Please specify the one to connect to by setting `address`.
```


 The second `sky run` will hit provision, which runs `ray up -y --no-restart` [here](https://github.com/concretevitamin/sky-experiments/blob/master/prototype/sky/backends/cloud_vm_ray_backend.py#L677-L686) which means the Ray processes are not started in this second run.

(The above can also be reproduced by running `exit 1` in a task's setup.  Then remove that problematic setup command and rerun. 
 This is a realistic user debugging flow!)

The correct fix seems to be
- after `ray up -y --no-restart`, check `ray status` on remote, if it fails, run `head_start_ray_commands` (and the worker counterpart).
- This is assuming we can't get rid of `--no-restart` for the reason documented in the code.

title: Sanitize cluster names / make names with underscores be able to run on GCP
body:
`multi_echo.py` was using the cluster name `multi_echo`.  When forcing it on GCP, it failed with

> googleapiclient.errors.HttpError: <HttpError 400 when requesting https://compute.googleapis.com/compute/v1/projects/intercloud-320520/zones/us-west1-a/instances?alt=json returned "Invalid value for field 'resource.name': 'ray-multi_echo-head-480dea0e'. Must be a match of regex '(?:[a-z](?:[-a-z0-9]{0,61}[a-z0-9])?)'". Details: "[{'message': "Invalid value for field 'resource.name': 'ray-multi_echo-head-480dea0e'. Must be a match of regex '(?:[a-z](?:[-a-z0-9]{0,61}[a-z0-9])?)'", 'domain': 'global', 'reason': 'invalid'}]">

Replacing the name with `multi-echo` worked.  It must be regex `(?:[a-z](?:[-a-z0-9]{0,61}[a-z0-9])?)`

Need to design a solution (force replace `_` with `-`?  some other approach?).

title: Cluster reuse and resize with `[gpu|cpu|tpu]node`
body:
Currently there is no mechanism to support reusing a stopped cluster for `gpunode`. Intuitively I would expect being able to launch `sky gpunode -c se01 --gpus K80 --cloud aws`, then do some stuff, `sky stop se01`. But there's no way for me to restart the cluster again. Intuitively something like `sky gpunode -c se01` should just restart the cluster. I know @concretevitamin is working on `sky start` to fix the re-use problem.

The other thing that should be considered is if we run something like this:
```
# starts a cluster named se01 with 1 V100 on AWS
sky gpunode -c se01 --gpus V100 --cloud aws

# do some stuff

sky stop se01

# now the same se01's instance type is changed 
# (equivalent to going into the AWS console and using "Change instance type")
# all data on the cluster's disk is the preserved
sky gpunode -c se01 --gpus V100:8
```

This seems like an intuitive behavior if we specify `--gpus` that are different from the GPUs we allocated initially, and resizing instances (at least in my experience) is a common thing.

In the future, we may also want to support changing clouds and having the data on that cluster migrate to the other cloud easily (but very low-pri for now).

title: Job Submission: Add support for job queue and management.
body:
This PR aims to provide better support for job queues with the support of `ray job`.

Main changes:
1. Replace the program submission logic with ray job.
2. New resource checking: task resources <= cluster.launched_resources.
3. New cli's for job queue.
4. Job queue information is stored on the database on cluster (for multitenancy) backed by sqlite3.
5. `sky logs` for tracking logs.

Added features:
1. `sky queue <cluster_name> [--all]` (--all: shows all the tasks including the finished ones; `sky queue cluster_name` will only show the finished task once).
```bash
> sky queue test --all
Sky Job Queue of Cluster: test
+-----+-------------+-----------+-----------------------------------------+
| JOB |  SUBMITTED  |   STATUS  | LOG                                     |
+-----+-------------+-----------+-----------------------------------------+
| 117 | 31 secs ago |  RUNNING  | sky_logs/sky-2022-01-05-15-57-40-379226 |
| 116 |  4 mins ago | SUCCEEDED | sky_logs/sky-2022-01-05-15-53-14-428524 |
| 115 |  5 mins ago |  STOPPED  | sky_logs/sky-2022-01-05-15-52-29-825712 |
| 114 |  5 mins ago | SUCCEEDED | sky_logs/sky-2022-01-05-15-52-12-210650 |
| 113 | 20 mins ago | SUCCEEDED | sky_logs/sky-2022-01-05-15-38-02-089872 |
+-----+-------------+-----------+-----------------------------------------+
```
2. `sky cancel -c <cluster_name> [<job_id>|--all]`
3. `sky logs -c <cluster_name> <job_id>`: tailing the log of a job in real time.
4. To do detached execution: `sky exec -c <cluster_name> yaml_file --detach`.

TODOs:
- [x] Tested examples/minimal.yaml with multiple jobs (including accelerators).
- [x] Better job name for user's convenience.
- [x] Tested single nodes/multiple jobs with less demanding resources. (`examples/job_queue/cluster.yaml`; `examples/job_queue/job.yaml`: two jobs with V100: 0.5)
```bash
Sky Job Queue of Cluster: test
+-----+-------------+-----------+-----------------------------------------+
| JOB |  SUBMITTED  |   STATUS  | LOG                                     |
+-----+-------------+-----------+-----------------------------------------+
| 124 | 12 secs ago |  PENDING  | sky_logs/sky-2022-01-05-16-14-49-575592 |
| 123 | 20 secs ago |  RUNNING  | sky_logs/sky-2022-01-05-16-14-41-608605 |
| 122 | 29 secs ago |  RUNNING  | sky_logs/sky-2022-01-05-16-14-30-905822 |
| 121 |  2 mins ago | SUCCEEDED | sky_logs/sky-2022-01-05-16-12-38-642178 |
+-----+-------------+-----------+-----------------------------------------+
```
- [x] Pipe logs and add hints.
- [x] Test multiple nodes multi-node job. (`examples/job_queue/multinode.yaml`; `examples/job_queue/multinode_job.yaml`: two jobs with 2x K80: 0.5)
- [x] Multiple nodes with single-node job. (`examples/job_queue/multinode.yaml` with 2x K80; `examples/job_queue/job.yaml`: two jobs with 1x K80: 0.5: 4 jobs in parallel)
- [x] Multiple nodes with single-node job and multi-node job.
- [x] Distributed training with multiple nodes.
- [x] Test `examples/run_smoke_tests.sh`
- [x] Deprecate the ParTask and rewrite ParTask examples.


Future:
- (! Important) Fix job execution order. (ray seems not preserving the FIFO order of the job queue).
```bash
Sky Job Queue of Cluster test2
+-----+------+------------+-----------+-----------------------------------------+
| JOB | USER | SUBMITTED  |   STATUS  | LOG                                     |
+-----+------+------------+-----------+-----------------------------------------+
| 103 | zhwu | 2 mins ago |  PENDING  | sky_logs/sky-2022-01-06-02-36-36-737105 |
| 105 | zhwu | 1 min ago  |  RUNNING  | sky_logs/sky-2022-01-06-02-37-03-308653 |
| 104 | zhwu | 1 min ago  |  RUNNING  | sky_logs/sky-2022-01-06-02-36-50-699314 |
| 102 | zhwu | 2 mins ago | SUCCEEDED | sky_logs/sky-2022-01-06-02-36-23-662007 |
| 101 | zhwu | 2 mins ago | SUCCEEDED | sky_logs/sky-2022-01-06-02-36-06-512089 |
+-----+------+------------+-----------+-----------------------------------------+
```
- Fix executing job with num_nodes=2 on a cluster with 3 nodes. (This is blocked by the `post_setup_fn` design for distributed training).
- Fix log downloading logic. （When should we download the logs? Zongheng: maybe don't).
- Launching cluster for a task with `K80: 0.5` should round to `K80: 1`.

title: Sky Run `--setup/-s` and Bash File as Argument
body:
*This PR has been split into 2 parts. The first part, which is non controversial, just adds bash command for Sky Run and Exec. The second part, which is this PR, does `sky run --setup` and allows for bash file as argument/input.


Changes:
- [x] Sky Exec can take in a command or shell script instead of only a yaml file
- [x] Sky Run can also take in a command or shell script instead of only a yaml file
- [x] Sky Run can take in `--setup/-s` for setup script. 


Some examples below...

Sky Run
```
  #  Pass in commands

  >> sky run -c name -s 'echo Hello World' 'echo Bye World'

  # Pass in shell script

  >> sky run -c name -s setup.sh run.sh
```

Sky Exec
```
  #  Pass in commands for execution

  >> sky exec -c name 'echo Hello World'

  # Pass in shell script for execution

  >> sky exec -c name run.sh
```

title: [CLI] Add native ssh/scp/rsync support and credential forwarding
body:
Creating a cluster will automatically add it to a user's local `.ssh/config`, which will allow them to use `ssh cluster_name` locally without any issues. This also gives VSCode the ability to see the cluster and use it with the very awesome Remote Dev extension. Clusters are removed from the local `~/.ssh/config` on `sky stop` or `sky down`.

Also does SSH agent forwarding so a user can interact with git repos as if they're on their local dev environment.
 
### Tests:
- [x] Creates a valid and usable ssh config when a new cluster is created
- [x] The correct usable ssh config is removed when cluster is stopped/down
- [x] Avoids overwriting an existing ssh config with the same name as the cluster and sensibly avoids name conflicts with the generated ssh config
- [x] Avoids removing an existing ssh config with the same name and finds and removes the correct sky-generated ssh config

title: `sky stop`: stopping clusters.
body:
Currently only works for AWS clusters due to limitations in ray autoscaler.

User flow (used as tests as well): provision -> `sky stop` -> `sky run -c` again, must restore the previously set-up nodes.
```bash


test 'sky run' reuse

  sky run -c min examples/minimal.yaml
  sky ssh min
  touch hi
  sky stop min

  # Shows STOPPED.
  sky status

  # ValueError: The cluster "min" appears to be down. Run a re-provisioning command again (e.g., sky run) and retry.
  sky exec -c min examples/minimal.yaml

  sky run -c min examples/minimal.yaml
  sky ssh min
  ls hi

test interactive nodes reuse

  sky cpunode
  sky stop <..>
  sky cpunode  # Reuse, same test as above.
```

title: Fix Azure restarting existing instance with different cluster_name
body: According to the [source code](https://github.com/ray-project/ray/blob/02465a6792ff625ceea60dae4ef3cbcb895ee083/python/ray/autoscaler/_private/_azure/node_provider.py#L76), for Azure, `ray` distinguishes different instances by the `resource_group`, instead of the `cluster_name`. Making `resource_group=cluster_name` for different clusters solves the problem in the title (the first problem in #110).

title: Use Sky to provision 8 VMs each with 8 GPUs
body:
Lianmin asked us if we can help him find a region with 8x p3.16xlarge VMs (each with 8 GPUs). They have been doing this search manually.

Our current provisioner's retry strategy doesn't work because we consider provisioning successful when the head node setup is complete. But due to Ray's annoying "provision head -> setup head -> provision workers -> setup workers" strategy, if we could not launch the other 7 nodes, we would hang at "waiting for cluster to be ready" state, without moving on to trying a different region.

Would be great to support their use case.

title: Sky init and cloud credentials for storage
body:
The `sky init` command will check credentials for all three clouds, and write the list of available clouds into the global user state. The optimizer will then only generate plans using the enabled clouds.

Demo:

```
$ sky init
Sky will use the following clouds to run jobs. To change this, configure
cloud access credentials, and rerun sky init.

  AWS: enabled
  Azure: enabled
  GCP: enabled
```

If some cloud is not logged in:
```
$ sky init
Sky will use the following clouds to run jobs. To change this, configure
cloud access credentials, and rerun sky init.

  AWS: enabled
  Checking Azure...ERROR: Please run 'az login' to setup account.
  Azure: disabled
    Reason: Azure CLI returned error.
  GCP: enabled
```

When a cloud is considered as "enabled", it is also ensured that the user's node, as well as any node launched with Sky, will have the access credentials to that cloud's storage.

When running jobs, the optimizer will skip the clouds that you are not logged in with. If you are not logged into GCP but specifies `Resources(GCP, ...)`, it would show an error before provisioning, like so:


## Notes for reviewers

1. ~~I changed `CloudStorage.is_directory` to `CloudStorage.is_file` because the latter is easier. ~~
    1. ~~In GCS, using `gsutil ls -d <url>` to check if `<url>` is a directory is hard: if <url> is a non-root directory (e.g. `gs://some-bucket/some-dir/`), it would return one line with just this dir with a trailing slash; if <url> is a bucket root directory (e.g. `gs://some-bucket`), then it would list all subdirectories in the bucket, which could be zero, one or more.~~ Reverted this and special-case handled GCS bucket URLs.
    2. On the other hand, `gsutil -q stat <url>` reliably returns 0 iff <url> is a file, and 1 otherwise. Same goes for `head_object` in AWS S3.
    3. This change will make it not able to check if `<url>` exists. But later the `aws sync / gsutil rsync` commands will surface this error, so I think it's okay.

2. The easiest way to authenticate `gsutil` is by [installing it with google-cloud-sdk](https://cloud.google.com/storage/docs/gsutil_install#authenticate); authenticating the standalone `gsutil` is no longer recommended (and more complicated). So I changed `GcsCloudStorage._GET_GSUTIL` to now install the full google-cloud-sdk.

title: Add LocalDockerBackend support to cli
body:
# LocalDockerBackend support in CLI
Adds a `--docker` flag to sky cli that uses the LocalDockerBackend to run the sky task. LocalDockerBackend behaves like any other sky backend, so sky launch, sky exec, sky status and sky down have the same behavior.

Here's a correspondence map to help understand how sky concepts map to Docker concepts:

* Sky cluster is a Docker container.
* Each task is mapped to a docker image. Docker caches individual layers of images behind the scenes, so image is built only the first time a task is run (unless the setup or workdir changes later).
* Provisioning involves building a docker image locally and creating a container with a sleep task (`tail -f /dev/null`). (Task run commands are not used as docker run commands because in docker, once the task exits, the container also terminates. The sleep task in our implementation keeps the container alive and allows us to use docker exec to run tasks.)
* Sky tasks are executed in the container (cluster) through docker exec. I.e., sky.execute calls docker.container.exec
* Sky stop is equivalent to sky down - both terminate the container.

# Notes
* GPU acceleration is available on containers where supported. (This is currently based on checking if nvidia-smi is installed, need to be fixed to check based on the output of nvidia-smi, (good catch gmittal!))
* Since there's no easy way to track the output of a docker exec command in detached mode, this backend does not support the `-d` flag (and consequently, job queue features are also not supported).
* Ctrl+C on a running command kills the process inside the container. (from the API, it's possible to let it run in the background. However, getting logs from the API is tricky - we can work around it in a future PR).
* This backend requires task.name to be set. This is a hard requirement because task.name is used as the image tag. Randomly generated task names aren't a clean solution because the user's local docker tag registry would get littered with multiple names (each time a task is run).
* There's no notion of resources - this can be constrained if required, but not implemented in this PR.

# Usage
Launch a task with `sky launch --docker`


title: [CLI] Speed up 'sky exec' for faster iterative development
body:
Make 'sky exec' 2x faster.

With PR:
```shell
  time sky run -c debug1 examples/minimal.yaml
    3:22.63 total

  time sky run -c debug1 examples/minimal.yaml
    35.960 total

  time sky exec -c debug1 examples/minimal.yaml
    7.724 total
```
Before PR:
```shell
  time sky run -c debug1 examples/minimal.yaml
    3:08.02 total

  time sky run -c debug1 examples/minimal.yaml
    33.590 total

  time sky exec -c debug1 examples/minimal.yaml
    16.593 total   
```
This was measured on my currently spotty network.  Can someone help measure the above at home?

Changes:
- Speed up sky exec by not using 'ray exec/rsync_up'
- ResourceHandle: is now a tuple (head_ip, yaml, tpu).
  - Uses the cached head_ip to directly run our own 'rsync', 'ssh <cmd>'.
  - Thus tpu management is nicely handled
- (Not back-compat) global_user_state: support pickle-able handles.
  - Run `rm ~/.sky/state.db`

title: [CLI] Add sky ssh and port-forwarding
body:
#87 
Enabled the cli: 
1. Attach and port forwarding to cluster: `sky ssh -p <port1> -p <port2> cluster_name` 
2. Port forwarding for gpu/cpunode: `sky gpunode -p <port1> -p <port2> ` 
3. `sky gpunode -c cluster_name` will carete the cluster with the name of cluster_name (rather than randomly generated one), if the provided cluster does not exist.

title: [CLI] Introduce `sky exec`; some more CLI fixes
body:
Introduce `sky exec` (I put reasons for this two-command approach in [this paragraph](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1Rjo7vvX4RjJ2f8prU5SbVQRLwbR5jhaTCL08rANJaSo/edit#heading=h.u4bze6a2k75k))
```
 » sky exec --help
Usage: sky exec [OPTIONS] ENTRY_POINT

  Execute a task from a YAML config on an existing cluster.

  Actions performed by this command only include:
    - workdir syncing
    - executing the task's run command
  `sky exec` is thus typically faster than `sky run`, provided a cluster
  already exists.

  All setup steps (provisioning, setup commands, file mounts syncing) are
  skipped.  If any of those specifications changed, this command will not
  reflect those changes.  To ensure a cluster's setup is up to date, use
  `sky run` instead.

  Typical workflow:

    # First command: set up the cluster once.

    >> sky run -c name app.yaml

    # Starting iterative development...
    # For example, modify local workdir code.
    # Future commands: simply execute the task on the launched cluster.

    >> sky exec -c name app.yaml

    # Simply do "sky run" again if anything other than Task.run is modified:

    >> sky run -c name app.yaml
```

Other important fixes:
- Remove _reuse_or_provision_cluster() in the 'sky run' codepath.  It was buggy because 
   - If cluster is not manually changed, it DOES NOT capture non-workdir file mounts content changes; 
   - If cluster is manually changed, skipping re-setup violates Task contracts.
- "sky run" -> manually modify ray.yml to change instance_type, "ray up" -> "sky run" -- before it didn't restore the instance_type, now it does.

title: CLI feature requests
body:
It seems we can `sky run <yaml file>`. Can we also have `sky run <python file>` for convenience?

-- updated --
[Whiteboard doc](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1Rjo7vvX4RjJ2f8prU5SbVQRLwbR5jhaTCL08rANJaSo/edit#)
### `sky status`
- [x] `sky status`
```bash
      | Cluster name | Launched | Resources | Status               |
      | sky-xxxx     | 2021-12  | 4 V100    | [stopped | running]  |
```
- For the resources column, an alternative is to show the detailed info using the following commend
  - `sky status --cluster <cluster_name>`

- [ ] `sky status --refresh` Partially satisfied with #653 
  - Update the status from the cloud services, since users may manually stop or terminate some machines.
  - Delete the whole cluster if the some node in the cluster is already terminated
- Lower priority:  `sky monitor --cluster cluster_name --gpu --cpu`
  - Show the resource utilization of the gpus and cpus, like the `gpuwatch blaze` on the RISE servers.
This would be very useful for the ML people.

### `sky down`
- [x] `sky down --all`
  - Stop all clusters, and change the status to be stopped
- `sky down --all --terminate/kill`
  - Terminate all clusters, and remove the clusters from the status table
Reason: user does not need to re-do the setup on the stopped instances, but still can save cost by stopping the cluster. By terminating the clusters, the user can save additional costs from the EBS.

### `sky info`
- [x] ~~`sky info`~~ Done by `sky show-gpus`
  - This is for showing the resources on the clouds. (similar to sinfo in slurm)
  - Show all instances on all available clouds.
- `sky info --accelerator V100 --cloud GCP`
  - Show all instances with V100 on GCP
 
### `sky cpu/gpunode`
Need an option that keeps the instance running, when the interactive session is logged out. This would be good when the user has unstable internet connection and want to connect back to the previous debugging session.

title: Avoid attempting to connect to GCP instance launched by other users
body:
When I tried to run the `resnet_app.py` example with `Resources(sky.GCP(), accelerator={'V100': 4})`, the sky will try to connect to the instance that was already launched by another user with only 1 V100 GPU, and raise the following error (the `f0eb6cb1` in the error message is the instance id launched by another user). The reason for it can be because we use the same `cluster_name` in the `gcp-ray.yml` for everyone.

```bash
Traceback (most recent call last):
```

title: Add support for cross-cloud retry
body:
The `execution_v3` will now support cross-cloud retry if an optimization function is provided. (It is still compatible with the previous examples). The retry logic is that if all the regions in one cloud with a certain `instance_type` fail to provision, it will call the optimize function again with that `instance_type` blocked for this task and retry. Therefore, it can easily support retrying different `instance_type`'s that satisfy the requirement in the future (For example, multiple single T4 machines for AWS). 

I also added a `blocked_clouds` option for the task, so that users can block the entire cloud they do not want to use. It can be used for later support of automatic credential detection. 

A way to improve the API of `optimize` and `execute` might be:
```python
optimize_fn = sky.Optimier(minimize=sky.Optimizer.COST)
sky.execute(dag, optimize_fn=optimize_fn)
```

title: Fix the incomplete logs
body: The previous implementation will cause incomplete stdout or stderr, since the `redirect_process_output` will return the stdout/stderr whenever it meets EOF, but the stderr sometimes may not finish when stdout reaches EOF.

title: Tasks have no default unique id/name
body:
In sky.Task, we do not have any unique identifier for a task. The `name` field is perhaps intended to be an identifier, but if it is not specified by the user, it defaults to `None`.

The LocalDockerBackend requires a unique identifier for each task so it can assign container names and track associated volume mounts assigned during build time. 

Possible solution: Randomly generate a task name if it is not specified by the user.

https://github.com/concretevitamin/sky-experiments/blob/517b97d102108f7a8cb2a0dbd1061f5b790f8af2/prototype/sky/task.py#L28-L44

title: Docker-in-Docker support and bugfixes
body:
Adds docker-in-docker support to enable #60 to run with the LocalDockerBackend. Also includes some bugfixes:

* Volume mounts were not being executed
* Debug commands printed to the user were incorrect
* Added checks for container status in `post_execute`

title: AWS Authentication Fix
body:
Fixes Issue #44. Sky used to check AWS Key-Pairs and if the Key-Pair name (`sky-key`) from AWS is the same as the name of the generated ssh-key pair, then all is good. 
However, this doesn't work when you try Sky on one server and move to a different server. This is because the `sky-key` on AWS EC2 Key-Pair (which came from the first server) has a different fingerprint than the `sky-key` generated on the different server.

Changes:
- [x] Sky now computes the fingerprint of the ssh-key and checks if both the name and fingerprints match between AWS and local 
- [x] New key name generated for AWS is a hash string

title: Fork sky.execute when stream_logs=False
body: Mainly looking at this from a UX perspective, but if you turn `stream_logs=False` (only pipe output to file, not stdout) you get this awkward interaction where sky execute still has control of the main terminal and it looks like it's just hanging while all the output goes to a logfile. Instead, we should run the process in the background and return control to the user's shell session so they can do other things (e.g. tail the logfile, launch another run, launch a gpunode, write code, etc.).

title: Prettier user-facing paths
body:
My previous commit turned this line
```
Created or updated file config/aws-ray.yml
```
into this
```
Created or updated file /Users/lsf/projects/sky-experiments/prototype/config/aws-ray.yml
```

This PR fixes that by making the user-facing path string relative again.

The reason I kept the internal config path string to be absolute paths is that 1) relative paths don't work in tests because tests are run from repository root, not sky project root, and 2) more importantly, relative paths won't work if we run the execution script anywhere else than from the sky project root. (e.g. if my cwd is `~/myproject`). Even if we use `sky run` there's still the cwd problem, which is why I think using abs paths is necessary.

title: Add logging for execution_v2
body:
Added the logging for the execution_v2 (as in #25 ). The behavior would be as follows:
1. All the provision information/task output will be written to files so that users can tail the files for the output.
2. If the `stream_logs` is set to true, the output provision logs will be streamed to the console if the `Shared connection to` appears in the output, so that only the succeeded `ray up`'s output will be shown in the console.

title: Experience with the Ray Tune example (Docker-based dry run would be very useful!)
body:
Most of my time spent making the Ray Tune example is to get the Python dependencies right. It turns out the example requires a specific pytorch-lightning version, implicitly depends on `torchvision`, etc, etc. Part of the blame goes to Ray Tune for not specifying a clean `requirements.txt` (https://github.com/ray-project/ray/issues/20601), but I guess this can be common for our users too.

In this case I think first debug iteratively using a local Docker would be very useful since it is much faster than waiting for VMs to spin up every time you change a line.

No action items; will try Romil's local Docker backend soon.
